When all the requests for protection have been made, he then requests the expulsion of pestilence: the pestilence of the sky, of the earth, the year, month, day, and hour, as well as devils and small kuei, also the expulsion of apparitions of the sky, the earth, the year, the month, the day, and the hour, and all other kinds of apparitions. For all it is necessary to get the yin chiao or the sheng chiao. If he gets the yang chiao, it is considered that the apparitions still have not yet gone, and the expelling and divination must continue. Finally, he requests the shen to release the soul and to pass judgment on the divination. Then he requests the shen to accept the animal offered.' [849] We have considered this to be a combination of purity and piety norms. Given the association of purity and piety norms with misfortune avoidance, they can be considered to be supernaturally enforced.
♠ other supernatural enforcement not related to piety ♣ ♥

Human Enforcement of Morality

♠ care/harm ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found very little information on care/harm and fairness/cheating norms. More material is needed.
♠ fairness/cheating ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found very little information on care/harm and fairness/cheating norms. More material is needed.
♠ in-group loyalty ♣ inferred present ♥ Reliable published material on the kinship system is sparse: 'Generally, Miao have been pressured to take Chinese surnames, which are transmitted patrilineally. Descent is said to be patrilineal, and in some places the Han patrilineage form has been adopted. However, matrilineal kin are important in some areas. In practice, there is strong evidence that the system is bilateral.' [850] 'No serious comparative study of kin terms and lineage organization is yet available, and some of the writings on the subject suggest Miao politeness in telling Han investigators what they want to hear.' [851] The monogamous family was the primary socio-economic unit, but ties with the extended family were important: 'The two-generation nuclear family is statistically the most common. Relations between spouses, and between parents and children, are more egalitarian than among the Han. Economic, social, and ritual ties are retained with natal kin. Visiting kinsfolk are welcome guests, and may come for extended visits.' [852] 'The basic social organization /sic/ of the Miao is the family, and moreover their family structure is the small family system, which consists of husband, wife, and children under age. This kind of small family system is the original system of the Miao. The Miao Fang Pei Lan, in the chapter on villages, says: “Among the Miao people father and sons and brothers do not live together in one house. When a son grows up he lives apart, erecting a new house and then there is another household.” Because of the small family system their living quarters as a rule consist of two or three rooms. In the house there is only one bed, and the husband, wife, and children all sleep on it together. When a girl grows up, a separate bed may be set up for her. As a rule the Miao practice monogamy. Sometimes they take a concubine, to live together with the wife, or to live separately. In the family economy, men and women share agricultural work, but household chores are mainly the women's responsibility. Family property consists of fields, houses, animals, and furniture, tools, and utensils. When the children grow up, a boy gets married at 17 or 18, and is given a certain amount of property in order to build a separate house and establish a family. A girl marries at fifteen or sixteen. So, the small family system among the Miao can always be maintained, and is not likely to be expanded.' [853] 'Because of strict adherence to the small family system, clan organization cannot develop. Among the pure Miao there are the following five surnames: Wu, Lung, Liao, Shih, and Ma. Such surnames as Yang, Shih, P'eng, Chang, and Hung were those of outsiders who married into Miao families and [Page 129] 93 cont. adopted their ways. Among the Shih /“rock”/ and Lung /“dragon”/ there are the Ta /“big”/ Shih and Shao /“small”/ Shih, the Ta Lung and Shao Lung. Shao Shih is also written with the character shih meaning “time,” and Shao Lung, also with the character lung meaning “eminent.” Although they have surnames, they do not have a closely knit organization of family clans, and so formerly they did not object to marriage between people of the same surname. However, no marriage was permitted between close relatives. In recent years they have come under Chinese influence, and know that people of the same surnames must not marry. Shao Shih /“small rock”/ was changed to be written with the character shih meaning “time,” and Shao Lung /“small dragon”/ was changed to be written with the character lung meaning “eminent,” in order to separate them from Ta Shih /“big rock”/ and Ta Lung /“big dragon”/, so that they could intermarry. Today, Miao family life has become more and more like that of the Chinese, and marriage and funeral rites largely follow Chinese customs, barely retaining remnants of some Miao customs.' [854] Graham describes arranged marriages: 'Sexual attraction naturally results in love affairs and love affairs naturally result in sexual intercourse. Sometimes this results in marriage but often it does not.' [855] 'Children are often married at a very early age. It is not uncommon for a child to be married when only three or four years old and most children are married by the time they are twelve. Of course these are not love matches, and serious love affairs later in life with men and women to whom they are not married are quite likely to occur.' [856] 'The normal way is for engagements to be made by the parents of the boy through go-betweens. The initiative is taken by the parents of the young man. When they have decided that they wish to make an engagement between their son and a certain girl, they call two go-betweens who are invited to a meal in the boy's home. A chicken is killed for the meal and its tongue, its bones and other parts of its body are examined to ascertain whether or not the circumstances are propitious.' [857] 'If the signs are propitious, the middle men proceed to the home of the girl. There they endeavor to secure a favorable reply from the girl's parents who in turn call in go-betweens. If her parents are favorable, the go-betweens are feasted and they proceed to determine the details of the gift which must be given by the boy's parents to those of the girl. The gift may include pork, domestic animals, rice, beans, corn, money, or any other commodity. When the engagement presents have been given and accepted by the girl's parents, the engagement is complete and is seldom broken. There is a second feast for the go-betweens and other friends at the time when the engagement gifts are presented. The engagement is a contract between the parents of the young people. While the bride is not actually purchased, the value of the gift often goes a long way towards securing a favorable decision by the girl's parents.' [858] 'When the go-betweens arrive at the home of the girl much of the work of making the engagement is often done by means of songs. By certain songs they announce their mission to the girl's parents. Other songs carry the work along, even to the matter of approximately arranging the gift. There are songs when the gifts are presented. Sometimes these songs take the form of contests when the two sets of go-betweens ridicule or try to outwit each other or see who can keep going the longest.' [859] Premarital sexual relations could culminate in marriage as well: 'When the parents are unwilling to marry off a daughter, or nobody seeks her hand in marriage, or when the parents are unable or fail to make an engagement for a son, the marriageable person endeavors to win a mate. For this purpose he or she goes to the market place on the third day of the third moon, at tuan yang □ on the fifth day of the [Page 36] fifth moon, or at some other convenient time, or attends one of the Miao feasts or festivals, or joins those playing on the mountain-sides at New Year time. Either the boy or the girl can make the first advances. The methods are to look lovingly with the eyes, to squeeze hands and to speak loving words. This is inconvenient if there are many people about. A boy may take a girl's handkerchief or a girl take a boy's. Then the person who gets the handkerchief goes away and the other says, “That person has taken my handkerchief. Stay here and I will go after him (or her).” Then in a quiet secluded place they make love. They say loving words, squeeze each other's hands, and embrace. A very great evidence of love is when one spits and the other swallows the spittal. Copulation often follows after which a handkerchief or a ring may be given by the boy to the girl or vice versa and they make a vow such as, “If you do not marry me and marry another, you must take this engagement present and eat it and then I will make no trouble.” It is believed by the Ch'uan Miao men that copulation is one of the surest ways to a woman's affection.' [860] 'Later the parents must be informed and they must secure go-betweens and arrange engagement presents and so on. If the parents do not agree, then the young people run away together or the man carries away the girl. Then all the neighbors and friends urge the parents to consent and if they still do not agree the neighbors and friends practically compel them to do so. The gifts to the girl's parents are generally less than they would have been if the young people had been engaged and married in the usual way.' [861] 'Marriage by capture is not unknown among the Ch'uan Miao. Sometimes the girls are quite willing to get married in this way, and it is said that happy marriages often result. Sometimes a man uses this method because he is in love with the girl.' [862] According to Ling et al, premarital sexual relations were common and tolerated: 'Among the Miao the premarital sex life of the young men and women is rather free. When a virgin has intercourse with a man, her parents know about it but do not forbid it. On the contrary, they consider this evidence that the man finds their daughter desirable. Sometimes, the girl brings home her lover, and her parents will kill a chicken to entertain him. There are even public houses set up specially for the use of young men and women to gather together. For instance, in Chapter II reference was made to the Pa Chai Miao, recorded in Yung-sui T'ing Chih, to the effect that an empty shed was built near the village, where unmarried men and women gathered together to sing. If a couple fell in love, a cow was sent as a betrothal gift. Again, the unmarried men among the Ch'ing Chiang He Miao were called “lohan”; in the spring they would [Page 130] 94 cont. carry wine and food up the mountain, singing and dancing reciprocally. Those who became fond of each other would drink from an ox horn. There is the custom among the Miao of dancing for the new year, dancing for the moon, and singing for autumn. On such occasions, young men and women form groups and sing in response to each other all night until daybreak. After singing they mix with each other, drinking and joking, even to the extent of having sexual relations. This is called fang yeh “going wild.”' [863] However, parental consent was still required for marriage: 'Although unmarried men and women are free to fall in love, marriage, however, requires parental consent as well as the approval of the maternal uncle of the girl. The He Miao of Ch'ing Chiang, Kweichow have a marriage custom where they betroth the daughter of a paternal aunt to be the daughter-in-law of a maternal uncle. Should the maternal uncle have no son, the girl's family has to pay a large sum of money to him. Without such a payment the girl all her life may not marry. The Miao, other than close paternal cousins not being suitable mates, they do not object to marriage between people of the same surname. However, maternal cousins may not marry. This is a survival from a matrilineal society, because in a matrilineal society maternal cousins have the same surname whereas cross cousins or male and female first cousins on the father's side have different surnames. That maternal cousins cannot marry is evidence of their advance from a matrilineal society to a patrilineal society. The importance of the maternal uncle's position in sacrificial ceremonies as well as in the society is additional evidence.' [864] Graham describes the proceedings at weddings: 'Parents generally desire to marry off their daughters, for it is the custom of marrying daughters into other homes that makes possible the securing of daughters-in-law to labor in the home and to give birth to descendants. Besides, the girl's parents receive engagement gifts and these are sometimes very valuable.' [865] 'The bride generally weeps before leaving her parental home. Sometimes the sorrow is pretended but at other times she is sad and unwilling to go and the parents and friends and relatives have to use persuasion and even cocrcion. There is an old custom by which the parents actually push the girl out of the house. It is customary for the girl and her parents to weep, either as a matter of form or because of sincere sorrow.' [866] 'Before the bride leaves her home, a meal is provided by her parents for her and for those who escort her. In the wedding procession there are generally one or more old women, relatives of the bride, a male relative or friend who manages the procession, the brothers of the bride and other friends who choose to go along. If it is a long distance to the groom's home, a meal is provided to be eaten by the way. In the bridal procession are generally carried such clothing, boxes, chests of drawers or other objects that have been given as bridal presents by her parents to the bride. The manager carries with him a bamboo tree with roots which symbolizes the large number of descendants of the couple. It is also supposed to have magic power to help the family thus to prosper. Sometimes a branch of a tea tree is also carried. Some plant the bamboo tree and others hang it up on the wall of the house. The liu shêng is not used at weddings for its notes are thought to be too sad for such occasions.' [867] 'On arriving at the home of the groom, the brothers of the bride generally escort her into the house as a protection from demons. If she has no brothers, first cousins will do and lacking these, other male relatives may be invited to act as brothers. When entering the house the bride covers her face with a black and a white cloth. Her older brother goes in front and she holds onto his belt. Behind her an older or younger brother holds an umbrella over her as protection from demons.' [868] 'Sometimes the bride and her companions enter the home and walk around in a circle three times. At other times, the Chinese custom of kowtowing three times to parents, relatives, and friends is followed. Tea is soon offered to the guests. According to an old custom that is no longer observed, the meat of a particular kind of bird and fish were provided at wedding feasts. There is always a wedding feast for the relatives and friends. One of the male relatives later counts before all the clothing, chests of drawers, and other things that have been sent along by the bride's parents. When her relatives and friends finally depart, the groom and his relatives go through a form of detaining her by force. This shows that [Page 38] they really want her but it is also true that brides sometimes run away at this time. Another ceremony that is sometimes performed at a wedding is that of calling the soul of the bride. Her soul may fail to come with her and if it does not come, she will die.' [869] 'After a few months have passed, the bride is permitted occasionally to visit her parents, but henceforth her husband's home is her home and his family is her family. She calls her husband's parents father and mother.' [870] 'During the marriage ceremonies offerings are generally made to the soil and to the ancestors who first gave grain to the Miao. These are regarded and treated practically as deities. There are two great demons or devils, and possibly three. gla□ d□y often drowns people in creeks and rivers. He seems to be related to the Chinese river demons who are the demons of people who are drowned themselves and who try to drown others so as to escape from their demon state. Some say that d□y means original and that gla□ d□y means original demon.' [871] Marriage customs changed under Chinese influence, but go-betweens remained important: 'The former marriage customs of the Miao were slightly different from their present ways. Yung-sui T'ing Chih says: “Miao marriage is just like a purchase. They do not follow the /Chinese/ custom of asking names (as a preliminary to fixing a betrothal) and sending presents to the bride's home to fix the betrothal. They only negotiate about the number of horses and cattle through a broker. The broker is a Miao marriage go-between. It definitely requires five or six horses or heads of cattle to initiate a trade for one wife. When the agreement [Page 131] 94 cont. is reached an inauspicious /sic/ day is chosen to welcome the wife. The bride wears a moon-white gown and walks holding a parasol, half open, half shut, called the shame-hiding parasol. Her father and mother, brothers, and relatives escort her to the husband's house. The dowry consists of everything from cattle and sheep and goats to plows and harrows. They do not enter by the main door but through a hole bored through a wall. Men and women sit together. The bride is not allowed to look left or right, or else the husband would be displeased for fear that shermay be fond of some one else. The couple takes each a bowl of rice, a piece of fish, and a cup of wine dregs. Next they visit the paternal uncles' houses in the same village, at each eating and drinking the same items. On their return home they are husband and wife, but they do not spend the night together.” It also says: “The Miao do not object to marriage between people of the same surname, but relatives do not marry. On the wedding night the bride sleeps with her mother, who leaves only when the groom gives her some silver as a gift 95, called the “mother's money” or “milk money.” It is generally about two or three liang of silver. A wealthy family, seeing a pretty girl, might order their son to drag the girl from behind. This is called “carrying off a woman and marrying her by force.” The girl's family attracted by their wealth, do not engage the girl to anyone else, but get a go-between to discuss betrothal presents. When a virgin has an affair with a man, her parents know about it but do not forbid it. On the contrary, they consider this evidence that the man finds her desirable. But, if one's wife or concubine is seduced, then they raise knives, facing each other, and money is required as compensation. If a husband and wife do not get along, the husband may divorce her and marry again, and the wife may do the same. As to improper sexual conduct, instances were very rare even in former days, and today the Miao have become more aware of ethical and moral obligations.” (What is recorded in the Miao Fang Pei Lan is to the same effect.)' [872] 'Today, the marriage customs of the Miao have been thoroughly influenced by the Chinese and have changed from the old ways. Boys and girls who like each other return home and tell their parents. The boy's family finds a go-between to approach the girl's family to discuss marriage. Once, twice, and sometimes three or four times, such approaches may be made before an agreement is reached. Having had indications of assent from the girl's family, the go-between goes back to report to the boy's family, who get ready two bottles of wine (a wealthy family would send along two chin of meat and two chin of noodles besides the wine). The gifts are carried back by the go-between to the girl's family, who invite him to drink wine and eat noodles. Where this procedure has been gone through then they reckon it to be the preliminary engagement, which in the Miao language is called (tiaŋ□ t□ mp`a□), meaning “to let the girl go,” also translated as /Chinese/ fang k'ou “to let go the mouth /door?/.”' [873] 'After the preliminary engagement a period of time is allowed to elapse. Then the ceremony of sticking in incense has to take place, which is called /soŋ□ t'i □/), with the meaning of /Chinese/ na ts'ai, i.e. the sending of gifts to the bride's home and fix the betrothal. The date is selected by the boy's family, who then informs the girl's family. The gifts generally consist of 50 or 60 strings of cash, one outfit of clothing, a pair of earrings, a pair of bracelets, a few boxes of rice cakes, two chin of sweetmeats, two packages of firecrackers, one chin of oil, one chin of salt, a jug of wine, and several chin of meat. The quantity of the foregoing gift items depends largely upon the financial condition of the boy's family. Poor families may omit a few items, but money, clothes, rings, bracelets, firecrackers, wine, meat, incense and candles are necessary items. These gifts are carried by the brothers of the future groom, followed by the go-between, the future groom, and his father, to the girl's family. Sometimes, the future groom may not go. When the gifts arrive at the door to the house, firecrackers are set off, and the party is received outside the door by the clan [Page 133] 95 cont. brothers in the girl's family. After entering the door and a brief rest, the ceremony of sticking incense before the ancestral tablet of the girl's family begins. The groom kowtows three times. If he is not present, his father kowtows in his place. If the groom is present he must also kowtow to his future father-in-law, mother-in-law, and other elders. If the girl's family is wealthy, then a pig will be killed to entertain the guests from the groom's family. The guests remain in the girl's family for three days, during which the immediate relative of the girl's family take turns in entertaining them with meals, called “meals from door to door.” The closest relatives must entertain the visitors at breakfast, because breakfast is considered the most important meal in the Miao countryside. For instance, say there are six families, A, B, C, D, E, and F, with A and C being the closest relatives. Dinner on the first (■)ening is given by the host family, 96 breakfast on the second day is given by family A, lunch by family E, and dinner by family B. On the third day breakfast is given by family C, lunch by family F, and dinner by family D. When the guests are seen off on the fourth day, breakfast is given by the host family. As a rule three meals are served in a day, but when there are a large number of /clan/ brothers there are five or six meals in one day. After breakfast on the fourth day the guests depart. Return presents from the girl's family consist of a suit of clothes, a pair of shoes, and a hat for the future son-in-law, a piece of material for a pair of trousers for each guest, a pair of shoes each for the parents of the groom, and a pig's leg for the gobetween.' [874] 'A few months or half a year before the marriage the gobetween visits the girl's family to ask for the date and time of her birth. He must bring with him two or four strings of cash and some sweetmeats. This ceremony is called “asking for the lucky birth date.” The girl's birth date and time thus obtained are matched with those of the groom in order to pick an auspicious day for the wedding. The date is communicated to the girl's family through the go-between. They then begin to [Page 134] 96 cont. get busy with the bride's marriage portion. Most commonly it consists of one or two trunks, four or five garments making one outfit, two pairs of trousers, and a suit of clothes for the groom. Such women's ornaments as earrings, rings, bracelets, and neck rings have been sent previously by the groom's family to the bride's, or silver is sent instead for the bride's family to have the ornaments made of it. On the day set the groom's family send along wine, meat, firecrackers, incense and candles, and torches, and recently they include sedan chairs or chairs. When they arrive before the entrance of the bride's family, recently, in imitation of the Chinese custom, they close the entrance and demand money for opening the gate in the sum of eight hundred cash or one string /one thousand/ of cash. Further, they intentionally curse the go-between and complain that the gifts of wine and meat sent by the boy's family are not enough. The bride then gets dressed up, and meanwhile a Miao sorcerer is invited to make sacrifices to the ancestors. A square table is laid with sacrificial items, incense and candles, and the sorcerer priest recites incantations, kowtows, and performs divination with straws, to cut off the powers of evil. He lights two torches, opens a parasol, and invites the bride to come out to kowtow three times to the ancestral tablet. After this she kowtows once to her parents, once to all her brothers and paternal male cousins, and once to her maternal grandparents. This done, she turns around facing outside and mounts the sedan chair (in a rich family) or walks (middle-class family), holding a half-opened parasol. The brothers, sisters, cousins, mother's married sisters, mother's brothers wives, and mother of the bride accompany her on the way. If the bride arrives too early at her husband's house, she has to wait in a side building or take a rest in a neighbor's house. At that time a table is laid in front of the entrance with incense and candles, a piece of cooked meat, and three cups of wine. A guest sorcerer offers the following prayer: “The day is auspicious, the moment is opportune, Heaven and earth open out. [Page 135] 96 cont. The bride arriving here brings Great luck and great prosperity. The peach tree is young and beautiful and upright! The maiden goes to her bridegroom's house to become a pair of phoenixes. Acting correctly toward the members of the family, she descends from the sedan chair, Lightly she moves with short steps into the decorated hall. The bride's family's carriage and horses turn and go back. The husband's carriage and horses come out to wel- come her. And after this exchange of carriages and horses, Heaven will be long and earth lasting; Earth will be lasting and heaven long.” At this point he takes hold of a cock and continues: “This chicken is not an ordinary one, It is the chicken which announces dawn to the Prince's Mother. Wearing a heroic comb and a fine beak, Dressed in silk gauze clothes in five hues, People of this world have no use for it.97 But I use it to exorcise evil influences, Of heaven and earth, Of the year, the month, the day, the hour, And of the twelve evil spirits. The evil influences of heaven return to heaven; Of the earth returns to Hades. Thus, the evil spirits retreat And the lucky stars descend.”' [875] 'On finishing the incantation he bites open the comb of the cock and sprays its blood on the ground. Returning to the house, he sets another square table like the one before and continues: “O! ye, holy spirits of the heavens And the holy spirits of the earth! [Page 136] 97 cont. I am invoking the benignant spirits of union To this mundane world. The mission is none other than To officiate at this marriage rite. We ask the Heaven Uniting Spirit, The Earth Uniting Spirit, The Year Uniting Spirit, The Day Uniting Spirit, The Hour Uniting Spirit, The twelve uniting spirits and twelve uniting fairies, Tung Wang Kung /Lord of the East, leader of the male immortals/ Hsi Wang Mu /Lady of the West, leader of the female immortals/ The Cowherd and the Weaving Girl /names of stars/ And the Old Immortal in the moon.”' [876] 'At this point he takes a cup of wine and a piece of meat, and writes out an incantation. After burning this he asks the groom to drink half of the wine and to eat half of the meat, the rest being for the bride when she comes in. These are called the uniting wine and the uniting meat. After the sorcerer priest has finished this performance, he sets off firecrackers and leads the bride into the house through a small side door. She sits down beside the fire pit, in which a huge fire has been started. The chair is placed slightly farther away for fear that the fire would give out too much heat. The chair cannot be pushed backward; it can only be pulled forward. The movement backward is recognized to be inauspicious; the forward movement then is auspicious. The sitting direction must be facing inside or in the direction of the ancestral tablet. After being seated she first washes her face with water. It has been boiled in a cooking pot with t'ung grass, pa-lun grass, and huang-mao grass, taken out and put in a basin, and incantations written and recited. While the bride is washing her face, the sorcerer priest sweeps with a broom several times behind her. After washing, she eats the meat and drinks the wine left by the groom. [Page 137] 97 cont. She is kept company by those who escorted her here. The brothers of the bride set the bridal chamber in order, and the groom's family gives them one or two strings of cash, a piece of meat, and two cups of wine. First half of the wine is spilled on the floor and the rest is drunk up, but the meat is all consumed. After these things have been done, the wedding feast begins. The dishes include beef, pork, bean-starch vermicelli, bean curd fried in oil, greens, etc. After the meal, the singing begins. Men and women guests gather in a group while men and women of the host family gather in another group. First the host of the groom's family begins to sing, (singing one of the “Welcoming the Bride Songs,” see the chapter, “Folk Songs,” no. 3). If the opposite side does not take up the singing, they use all means to encourage them. The phrases sung generally consist first of polite exchanges. In addition they sing legends, do Chinese characters, make riddles, and praise each other, etc. In the singing there is winning and losing: for instance, if A 's singing says B is polite, and B is not able to answer, saying he is not polite, then B is reckoned the loser; or if B sings that he himself is ignorant of etiquette, and A fails to sing back of his skill in etiquette, then B is the winner. Again, if A sings the name of a personage of antiquity whom B does not know, or if A offers a riddle which B fails to solve - these would be reckoned losing counts for B. The loser can no longer participate in the singing, and if a whole group fails to sing back the answer to the opposite side, then the whole group loses out. Experts in singing can match songs back and forth all night to a draw. 98 In the middle of the night they eat mi-pa /rice cakes/ as refreshments. In the singing the women keep things going, for they bring up subjects to be answered by the men. Ordinarily men are easily defeated, because women lose only when they can pick no more subjects for the men to answer. Sometimes the singing lasts for three nights, but usually one or two nights (see chapter, on “Folk Songs,” nos. four to 13, “Welcoming the Bride Songs,” and nos. 14 to 18, “Songs Sung in Company”). The guests remain [Page 138] 98 cont. for three days, the same as at the time of “sticking in incense.” They are also entertained in rotation by the closest relatives of the host. After breakfast on the third day a large table is set up in the main room. Eloquent elder men and women of the two families are invited to sit down around the table to count and announce the number of presents from the bride's family. First, the suit, shoes, and hat from the bride's parents to the son-in-law are announced, next the material for trousers from the guests to the groom, and then the presents from the bride's family to the elders of the groom's family. Then they record the cash and articles presented by the groom's family in return to the bride's family. For instance, if the dowry from the girl's family was 80 strings of cash, the groom's family returns 50. In a family of wealth, this money is usually left with the bride and not taken back. The guests who presented trousers receive one or two strings of cash in return. The bridesmaids also receive one or two strings of cash. The bride's family receives a pig's leg, and the go-between gets a pig's head. While the presents are being announced, the men and women sitting around the table talk and sing, in response to each other. (See Chapter 11, “Folk Songs,” songs no. 19, 20, 21, and 22, “Seeing the Guests off on the Third Morning.) During these three days the bride and groom do not share the same room. When the bride's family is escorted back, the bride goes along and stays for one or three days before she comes back to her new home to share the room with the groom.' [877] Divorce was tolerated and fairly easy to obtain: 'Divorces are very easy with the Miao. The lack of good looks, a difference in wealth between the families, incompatibility, lack of good behavior - any of these constitutes grounds for divorce. Either side may initiate a divorce action. The children of a divorced couple are generally kept by the man, but an unweaned baby is kept by the woman to be restored to the man when it grows up. If the man's family is destitute, the children are kept by the woman's family. After the divorce either side may remarry at will.' [878] Widows were free to re-marry, but required the approval of her brothers-in-law, who might pursue levirate marriage: 'A widow has freedom of sexual intercourse. There is no definite period of mourning for her deceased husband and she may remarry at any time, except that she must have the approval of the brothers of the deceased husband. If either the elder or the younger brother of the deceased wishes to marry the widowed sister-in-law, then she may not marry an outsider. Otherwise she returns to her family to marry again. At the time of the second marriage a sorcerer priest is also asked to perform the ritual. There is no go-between nor a formally set date. At the wedding the “shame-covering parasol” must be opened fully. On reaching her new husband's home she enters by the front entrance.99 A widow may marry again and again. Furthermore, she can have a husband marry into her household.' [879]
♠ respect for authority ♣ present ♥ Uprisings against the Chinese administration were common and Chinese authority was resented: 'Chinese scholarship links the present-day Miao to tribal confederations that moved southward some 2,000 years ago from the plain between the Yellow River and the Yangtze toward the Dongting Lake area. These became the San Miao mentioned in Han dynasty texts. Over the next thousand years, between the Han and the Song dynasties, these presumed ancestors of the Miao continued to migrate westward and southward, under pressure from expanding Han populations and the imperial armies. Chinese texts and Miao oral history establish that over those years the ancestors settled in western Hunan and Guizhou, with some moving south into Guangxi or west along the Wu River to southeastern Sichuan and into Yunnan. The period was marked by a number of uprisings and battles between Miao and the Han or local indigenous groups, recalled in the oral histories of local groups. Though the term "Miao" was sometimes used in Tang and Song histories, the more usual term was "Man," meaning "barbarians." Migration continued through the Yuan, Ming, and early Qing, with some groups moving into mainland Southeast Asia. The retreat from Han control brought some into territories controlled by the Yi in northeast Yunnan/northwest Guizhou. The various migrations can also be seen as "vertical" migrations into the undeveloped hillside and mountain areas that were of lesser interest to Han. Depending on the terrain, the settled farming cited in Miao historical myths gave way to shifting slash-and-burn agriculture, facilitated by the introduction of the Irish potato and maize in the sixteenth century, and the adoption of high-altitude/cool-weather crops like barley, buckwheat, and oats. Farming was supplemented by forest hunting, fishing, gathering, and pastoralism. During the Qing, uprisings and military encounters escalated. There were major disturbances in western Hunan (1795-1806) and a continuous series of rebellions in Guizhou (1854-1872). Chinese policies toward the Miao shifted among assimilation, containment in "stockaded villages," dispersal, removal, and extermination. The frequent threat of "Miao rebellion" caused considerable anxiety to the state; in actuality, many of these uprisings included Bouyei, Dong, Hui, and other ethnic groups, including Han settlers and demobilized soldiers. At issue were heavy taxation, rising landlordism, rivalries over local resources, and official corruption. One of the last Miao uprisings occurred in 1936 in western Hunan in opposition to Guomindang (Republican) continuation of the tuntian system, which forced the peasants to open up new lands and grow crops for the state.' [880] 'From Song on, in periods of relative peace, government control was exercised through the tusi system of indirect rule by appointed native headmen who collected taxes, organized corvée, and kept the peace. Miao filled this role in Hunan and eastern Guizhou, but farther west the rulers were often drawn from a hereditary Yi nobility, a system that lasted into the twentieth century. In Guizhou, some tusi claimed Han ancestry, but were probably drawn from the ranks of assimilated Bouyei, Dong, and Miao. Government documents refer to the "Sheng Miao" (raw Miao), meaning those living in areas beyond government control and not paying taxes or labor service to the state. In the sixteenth century, in the more pacified areas, the implementation of the policy of gaitu guiliu began the replacement of native rulers with regular civilian and military officials, a few of whom were drawn from assimilated minority families. Land became a commodity, creating both landlords and some freeholding peasants in the areas affected. In the Yunnan-Guizhou border area, the tusi system continued and Miao purchase of land and participation in local markets was restricted by law until the Republican period (1911-1949).' [881] Most Hmong were either tenants or smallholders, and accordingly occupied the lower strata of the 'free' population in the area: 'Prior to the 1950s land reform, some Miao were smallholders. Many, if not most, were tenants on lands owned by Han, Yi, Hui, and others. Few were true landlords, and most who rented out land were likely to work part of their holdings themselves with family labor. All land is now owned by the state, including undeveloped mountain and forest lands, thus limiting any expansion beyond lands officially assigned to an individual or village. In the process, pastoralism and forest hunting/gathering have been reduced. Before land reform, some Miao areas followed the practice of lineage or hamlet ownership of mountain and hillside lands even where some private holdings existed. People could open new lands for farming and settlement, share village pastures, or hunt away from their home area.' [882] Hmong society was not stratified: 'The various Miao groups are for the most part an unstratified agricultural people found in the uplands of several provinces of China and related to the Hmong of Southeast Asia. They are distinguished by language, dress, historical traditions, and cultural practice from neighboring ethnic groups and the dominant Han Chinese. They are not culturally homogeneous and the differences between local Miao cultures are often as great as between Miao and non-Miao neighbors. The term "Miao" is Chinese, and means "weeds" or "sprouts." Chinese minority policies since the 1950s treat these diverse groups as a single nationality and associate them with the San Miao Kingdom of central China mentioned in histories of the Han dynasty (200 BC-AD 200).' [883] 'Given the long period of Chinese rule, it is not possible to reconstruct precontact organization, though some areas still retain older lineage and clan names. Owing to dispersion, population decimation, and frequent migration, the multisurname settlement seems to be the most common. There was little class differentiation in the villages, and no formal political structure. Villages do not seem to have been formally linked by any kind of tribal organization and there was no formal political structure within villages.' [884] But respected elders served as informal leaders: 'Respected knowledgeable elders, heads of family groups, and religious experts of both genders served as informal leaders. Among the more Sinicized, landlords and those who had some literacy in Chinese exercised power in the community. Under the present system, those who are members of the Communist party stand as the official leaders of the community.' [885] Children were expected to defer to and respect their grandparents: 'Grandparents and grandchildren. The Magpie Miao have one elementary term (12) for paternal grandfather and a second (14) for paternal grandmother. A third term (15) is suffixed to the one or the other to designate maternal grandparents or may stand alone for MoMo. A single elementary term (16) denotes grandson; when prefixed by the term for daughter (4) it denotes a granddaughter.' [886] 'The interaction between grandparents and grandchildren is characterized by helpfulness and affection on the part of the former and by deference on the part of the latter. A grandfather often instructs his grandson in ritual observances, and a grandmother assists in the domestic training of her granddaughter. Both manifest a warm interest in their grandchildren and take pleasure in playing with them in their leisure time.' [887] The relationship with parents-in-law was characterized by deference and avoidance: 'The relationships between affines are more complex. A son-in-law defers to [Page 155] the opinions of his wife's parents, and his respect for them approaches avoidance in the case of his mother-in-law. Avoidance also prevails between a daughter-in-law and her husband's father, and the former is expected to be obedient toward her mother-in-law. A woman displays reserve in her relationship with her husband's elder brother. She avoids familiar conversation with him and refrains from walking beside him in public.' [888] Elders were deferred to in public meetings: 'Whenever there is an emergency that requires a public meeting, the drum tower keeper, also known as messenger (or footman, who receives as remuneration from the village 1,000 catties of grain a year), would climb up the wooden pillar to beat the drum at the top, crying loudly at the same time. The tempo and the number of the beats vary according to a fixed set of rules. The “tum, tum” beats can be heard within a radius of many li. The first drum beat signifies a call for a meeting for some important affair, and upon hearing it, the villagers would abandon their work to listen attentively.192 The second drum beat is an urgent call to gather together at the drum tower, and the third drum beat is a signal for the meeting to start. Ordinarily, after the third beat each family would have without fail a representative at the drum tower. At the meeting the old people would have the [Page 109] 192 cont. floor first to state the facts and express their opinions. Then they huddle up to discuss the matter and reach a decision, after which they turn around to ask the young people whether or not they agree. In general, though policy decision is made by the elders, its execution is undertaken by the young, and therefore the approval of the latter is necessary. At the meeting they squat around helter-skelter, seemingly confused and without any procedure, but the spirit animating the meeting has a special merit. They have complete freedom of speech, anyone being able to express his opinion to his heart's content. The young as a rule have high respects for the old, and recognizing the latter's extensive knowledge, they are willing to leave all the decisions to the elders without offering any opinion of their own. They believe that they are only good for carrying out the decisions. So on all important affairs the old people express their ideas, and when approved by the young, the work is distributed and assigned for action without delay.' [889] Due to the respect given to elders, we have coded the variable 'present', even in the absence of internal stratification.
♠ purity ♣ present ♥ Some sacrificial ceremonies had purifying aspects: 'Although the routine sacrifice is not held for any particular reason, its object is nevertheless the avoidance of calamities and the seeking of blessings. The “Sacrifice to the Ancestors” and “Eating Pigs” of the Miao religion and the “Local Divinity of the Soil” and the “Flying Mountain” ceremonies of the guest religion are all for the purpose of beseeching the kuei not to make trouble and seeking their protection. The special sacrifices for the avoidance of calamities may be divided into four categories: (1) for seeking a cure upon suffering illness; (2) for seeking cleansing after seeing a supernatural phenomenon or after any unlucky matter; (3) for seeking the resolution of a conflict that has arisen; (4) for seeking pardon for sins after death. Those sacrifices for the invocation of blessings may be divided into two categories; (1) to ask for wealth; (2) to ask for children. But there are many ceremonies which on one hand are to avoid calamities, and 130 at the same time are also ones which seek blessings. “Bludgeoning the Ox” of the Miao religion can be performed both for the cure of sickness and can also be performed to ask for children. “Redeeming a Vow to the No” of the guest religion may be performed for the cure of illness or to ask for wealth or children, or can be performed for all of these.' [890] 'Among the 16 ceremonies of sacrifice to the kuei of the Miao religion that we were able to investigate, the “Sacrifice” to the “Ancestors” and “Eating Pigs” are routine sacrifices; “Ta Chia Hsien,” “Redeeming the Soul,” “Sacrifice to the Kuei of Pimples,” and “Bludgeoning the Ox” are for seeking cures for sickness; the “Ta Kan Lo,” “Sending Away the Supernatural Forces of the Old Tree,” “washing the cat,” and “washing the house” are for seeking cleansing after seeing a strange phenomenon or something unlucky; “Eating Blood” is for seeking resolution of a conflict that has arisen; and “Releasing the Soul of the Dead from Suffering” is for asking forgiveness of a dead person's sins. All the above, except for “Bludgeoning the Ox,” which asks for a son at the same time, are ceremonies performed for the avoidance of calamities.' [891] Taboos related to polluting substances were observed before the performance of some sacrifices: 'After the autumn harvest has been completed and the first frost has arrived, an auspicious day is chosen to sacrifice to the kuei. Half a month before, four paternal male cousins are asked to go separately to where the relatives live to notify them. The most important relatives are the families of the hosts mother's brother and the wife's maternal uncle, who are said to be the “leg-bearing relatives.” They are so-called because after sacrificing to the kuei, one leg of the buffalo is given to the maternal uncle's relatives. A buffalo is divided into four legs. The first belongs to the /host's/ mother's brother, the second to the wife's maternal uncle, and the third and fourth are sent to other close relatives. The “leg-bearing relatives on receiving the notification presents the messenger with a strip of red cloth as an expression of gratitude. Moreover, within the 12 days before the sacrifice, one must avoid seeing unclean things, such as a dead cat, a dead dog, or a dead person. If this avoidance is violated, then the person may not be in the company of the buffalo kuei. The “leg-bearing” relatives often go together with the clan brothers /of the host/, making up a number of at least ten or more men up to as many as 60 or 70. Also invited are musicians, trumpeteers /?/, and drummers, to go in formation. Wealthy families imitate the old customs of the former Manchu dynasty, displaying official insignia, playing fine music, and beating gongs and carrying parasols. The maternal uncle's family entitled to the first leg [Page 209] 141 cont. also must provide a sharp spear and a large creeper. The spear is used to stab the ox, and the creeper, to tie its head.' [892] House-cleansing ceremonies were also performed: 'If one's house has been lived in by a family of a different surname, the master of the house must ask a Miao sorcerer to cleanse the house after that family moves out, otherwise, the owner after living there would not be prosperous. Cleansing the house in Miao is called [ndz(ə)□ p□γλ]. The two kuei invoked are [dei□ noŋγ d□] and [dei□ Iαγ noŋγ qa□]. The time is any time during broad daylight, and the place may be anywhere inside the house, either in the main room or in the side room, facing outside the door. A table is set up, and on it placed five bowls of wine, five pieces of pork, five piles of mi-pa, and five pieces of tofu/bean curd/. A piece of green cloth 6 ch'ih long is spread out on the ground under the table. On the cloth are one or two strings of copper yuan: they also use a cock, whose two wings are tied to a leg of the table. They do not use beeswax, but only use three slender sticks of incense stuck up in the mi-pa. The [Page 225] 151 cont. sorcer-priest holds the chiao and rings the bell, standing in front of the table, and the words of the incantation he utters are to the following effect: “Now we have prepared well wine, meat, a cock, pa-pa, tofu, green cloth, clean water, and ready money to cleanse the house. First we invoke the ancestors of the host. When you hear my call, please hurry down and receive the objects of sacrifice. Next we invoke the ancestors of the previous tenant. The host, fearing that he may not be at peace here, has asked me to come to cleanse the house. I have come with many soldiers and horses. With water I cleanse the house, first cleanse the fire bed, next the fire pit. I cleanse the right and the left of the house; I cleanse the front and the back doors. After I have cleansed three times, the host may live in it with great prosperity, resources abundant, prosperous harvests of the five grains, and the increase of the six kinds of domestic animals. The trouble-making kuei have now been sent out the door, hereafter peace will be everlasting.” After the incantation has been completed, he then divines with the chiao. If either the yang chiao or the sheng chiao appears, it is auspicious, and paper is burned to send off the kuei. But if the yin chiao appears, then the incantation has to be said again, until he divines and gets either the yang chiao or the sheng chiao, when it is the end. After the sorcerer-priest has completed his performance, he drinks the wine on the table and takes the cock, meat, pa-pa, tofu, green cloth, and copper yuan offered in sacrifice to the kuei, home with him.' [893] 'The Miao consider that a cat dying in the house is an ill omen, and it is then necessary to ask a sorcerer-priest to purify the house in order to expel harmful emanations. In Miao this is called [Page 226] 152 cont. [t□γ □ -mαŋ□]. The kuei sacrificed to are [kueŋγ mαŋλ jeŋ□ □iγŋ□] and [kueŋγ jeŋ□ □iαŋ□]. The time is in broad daylight and the place is anywhere in the main house; it is only necessary to face out the door. A table is used on which are placed five bowls each of wine and meat, placed in two rows. The beeswax is not used. The sorcerer-priest holds the chiao in his right hand and utters words of an incantation, which say in general: “The reason for sacrificing to the kuei is because a cat died in the house. Since the cat died in the house, the host dares not sit down in this house to eat food for fear that he may get sick after eating; he dares not live in this house for fear that he will not prosper. Therefore, I request the kuei to come to drive the dead cat away.” After the incantation he divines with the chiao. The yin chiao or the sheng chiao indicates that the kuei of the cat has already gone; if he gets the yang chiao, then the kuei still remains in house. Then the incantation has to be started all over again until the divination shows that the cat kuei is gone, whereupon the paper money may be burned to send off the kuei.' [894] Sacrificial objects were ritually cleansed: 'The first part is An Szu Ming “calming the god of the kitchen.” It is performed at dawn. The sorcerer-priest wears a red kerchief around his head and holds a chiao-tzu. Standing in front of a winnowing basket set in front of the Peach Spring cave, he makes a low bow to the No shen with his hands in front, and utters an incantation to ask his patron saint to possess his body and to ask the ancestors of the host's family to come down. On finishing his incantation, he picks up a bowl of water with his left hand and makes his patron saint's esoteric gestures with his right hand, as if writing, facing the bowl of water. At the same time he also utters the incantation for cleansing the sacrificial objects. First he speaks of the origin of water; next he flicks some drops of water on the offerings with his fingers. The Miao think that the Szu Ming shen abstains from meat, wine, garlic, etc., and therefore the things have to be cleansed. After the cleansing, he divines with the chiao-tzu, and stops if [Page 269] Illus. 75. Images of Duke (■)o and Mother No. [Page 270] 179 cont. he gets the sheng chiao. Otherwise, the incantation and the divination are repeated. After cleansing the objects of the sacrifice, the sorcerer-priest then utters the incantation to invite the shen, and when the sheng chiao appears, the shen are considered to have come down. Then he gives the reason for the sacrifice of fulfilling the vow to the No, and asks the shen to accept the offerings. When the sheng chiao again appears, it is considered that the shen have accepted the offerings. Then for the whole family, big and small, one by one, he asks the protection of the shen, and one by one he divines to get the sheng chiao. Then he asks for protection for the six kinds of domestic animals and the five grains, and also asks for good fortune. When all the requests for protection have been made, he then requests the expulsion of pestilence: the pestilence of the sky, of the earth, the year, month, day, and hour, as well as devils and small kuei, also the expulsion of apparitions of the sky, the earth, the year, the month, the day, and the hour, and all other kinds of apparitions. For all it is necessary to get the yin chiao or the sheng chiao. If he gets the yang chiao, it is considered that the apparitions still have not yet gone, and the expelling and divination must continue. Finally, he requests the shen to release the soul and to pass judgment on the divination. Then he requests the shen to accept the animal offered.' [895]
♠ kinship ♣ present ♥ Reliable published material on the kinship system is sparse: 'Generally, Miao have been pressured to take Chinese surnames, which are transmitted patrilineally. Descent is said to be patrilineal, and in some places the Han patrilineage form has been adopted. However, matrilineal kin are important in some areas. In practice, there is strong evidence that the system is bilateral.' [896] 'No serious comparative study of kin terms and lineage organization is yet available, and some of the writings on the subject suggest Miao politeness in telling Han investigators what they want to hear.' [897] eHRAF provides a general description of the marriage system: 'Marriages generally require parental consent but are based on mutual attraction and choice. In the past, many communities had "youth houses" where unmarried young people could gather. Groups of young men traveled around to court girls in other villages. In the absence of parental consent, elopement was an alternative. Festivals and trips to periodic markets still provide an opportunity for young people to meet, engage in antiphonal singing and dancing, and establish new friendships. Since the 1950s, travel restrictions and state disapproval of premarital sexual behavior has increased the parental role in marriage arrangement. Marriages are monogamous. Marriage outside the dialect or language group is rare. Divorce and remarriages are permitted. Postmarital residence is usually in the man's home village but only the youngest son lives with his parents after his marriage, and in instances where there are no sons a family may bring in a son-in-law or an aged widow or widower might join her married daughter's household. In some areas, there is delayed transfer of the bride until after the birth of her first child, or the practice of starting out with residence with the bride's family.' [898] The monogamous family was the primary socio-economic unit, but ties with the extended family were important: 'The two-generation nuclear family is statistically the most common. Relations between spouses, and between parents and children, are more egalitarian than among the Han. Economic, social, and ritual ties are retained with natal kin. Visiting kinsfolk are welcome guests, and may come for extended visits.' [899] 'The basic social organization /sic/ of the Miao is the family, and moreover their family structure is the small family system, which consists of husband, wife, and children under age. This kind of small family system is the original system of the Miao. The Miao Fang Pei Lan, in the chapter on villages, says: “Among the Miao people father and sons and brothers do not live together in one house. When a son grows up he lives apart, erecting a new house and then there is another household.” Because of the small family system their living quarters as a rule consist of two or three rooms. In the house there is only one bed, and the husband, wife, and children all sleep on it together. When a girl grows up, a separate bed may be set up for her. As a rule the Miao practice monogamy. Sometimes they take a concubine, to live together with the wife, or to live separately. In the family economy, men and women share agricultural work, but household chores are mainly the women's responsibility. Family property consists of fields, houses, animals, and furniture, tools, and utensils. When the children grow up, a boy gets married at 17 or 18, and is given a certain amount of property in order to build a separate house and establish a family. A girl marries at fifteen or sixteen. So, the small family system among the Miao can always be maintained, and is not likely to be expanded.' [900] 'Because of strict adherence to the small family system, clan organization cannot develop. Among the pure Miao there are the following five surnames: Wu, Lung, Liao, Shih, and Ma. Such surnames as Yang, Shih, P'eng, Chang, and Hung were those of outsiders who married into Miao families and [Page 129] 93 cont. adopted their ways. Among the Shih /“rock”/ and Lung /“dragon”/ there are the Ta /“big”/ Shih and Shao /“small”/ Shih, the Ta Lung and Shao Lung. Shao Shih is also written with the character shih meaning “time,” and Shao Lung, also with the character lung meaning “eminent.” Although they have surnames, they do not have a closely knit organization of family clans, and so formerly they did not object to marriage between people of the same surname. However, no marriage was permitted between close relatives. In recent years they have come under Chinese influence, and know that people of the same surnames must not marry. Shao Shih /“small rock”/ was changed to be written with the character shih meaning “time,” and Shao Lung /“small dragon”/ was changed to be written with the character lung meaning “eminent,” in order to separate them from Ta Shih /“big rock”/ and Ta Lung /“big dragon”/, so that they could intermarry. Today, Miao family life has become more and more like that of the Chinese, and marriage and funeral rites largely follow Chinese customs, barely retaining remnants of some Miao customs.' [901] Extended kin played a special role in some sacrifical family feasts: 'After the autumn harvest has been completed and the first frost has arrived, an auspicious day is chosen to sacrifice to the kuei. Half a month before, four paternal male cousins are asked to go separately to where the relatives live to notify them. The most important relatives are the families of the hosts mother's brother and the wife's maternal uncle, who are said to be the “leg-bearing relatives.” They are so-called because after sacrificing to the kuei, one leg of the buffalo is given to the maternal uncle's relatives. A buffalo is divided into four legs. The first belongs to the /host's/ mother's brother, the second to the wife's maternal uncle, and the third and fourth are sent to other close relatives. The “leg-bearing relatives on receiving the notification presents the messenger with a strip of red cloth as an expression of gratitude. Moreover, within the 12 days before the sacrifice, one must avoid seeing unclean things, such as a dead cat, a dead dog, or a dead person. If this avoidance is violated, then the person may not be in the company of the buffalo kuei. The “leg-bearing” relatives often go together with the clan brothers /of the host/, making up a number of at least ten or more men up to as many as 60 or 70. Also invited are musicians, trumpeteers /?/, and drummers, to go in formation. Wealthy families imitate the old customs of the former Manchu dynasty, displaying official insignia, playing fine music, and beating gongs and carrying parasols. The maternal uncle's family entitled to the first leg [Page 209] 141 cont. also must provide a sharp spear and a large creeper. The spear is used to stab the ox, and the creeper, to tie its head.' [902] The consent of parents and maternal uncles was required for marriage: 'Although unmarried men and women are free to fall in love, marriage, however, requires parental consent as well as the approval of the maternal uncle of the girl. The He Miao of Ch'ing Chiang, Kweichow have a marriage custom where they betroth the daughter of a paternal aunt to be the daughter-in-law of a maternal uncle. Should the maternal uncle have no son, the girl's family has to pay a large sum of money to him. Without such a payment the girl all her life may not marry. The Miao, other than close paternal cousins not being suitable mates, they do not object to marriage between people of the same surname. However, maternal cousins may not marry. This is a survival from a matrilineal society, because in a matrilineal society maternal cousins have the same surname whereas cross cousins or male and female first cousins on the father's side have different surnames. That maternal cousins cannot marry is evidence of their advance from a matrilineal society to a patrilineal society. The importance of the maternal uncle's position in sacrificial ceremonies as well as in the society is additional evidence.' [903] Graham treats family name complexes as clans, but reports no 'tribal' organization: 'There is also the family in the largest sense, which we may call the clan. All male persons of the same name, whether or not they are related to the others by birth, their unmarried daughters, their wives and the wives of their male descendants, are regarded as related. A person can remain indefinitely in the home of a family to which he is not related by birth but having the same family name and he pays nothing for his food and does not easily wear out his welcome. It is considered a crime for two persons having the same family name to marry although there is no known relationship. There are certain memorial ceremonies in which all partipate who have the same family name, for all such are regarded as blood relatives, especially if they can trace their descent to the same legendary ancestor.' [904] 'It is noteworthy that all Ch'uan Miao who have the same name can participate in this ceremony, not merely those who are known to be related. It indicates that the clan idea still survives and that all having the same surname are regarded as relatives.' [905] 'There is no tribal organization. That is, there is no political organization that extends throughout the entire ethnic group. A locality may elect a headman, called a gy l□u or old club, and the headmen of several different districts may cooperate for the general good, but the headmen are not bound together by an organization affecting the entire Ch'uan Miao region. If the Ch'uan Miao are a tribe, it is because they are physically related and have a common language, common customs, common ideals, and a common culture. These bind the people together more securely than could any political organization.' [906] Ancestors were important: 'The above diagram gives the names of eight generations of the Ch'uan Miao. The names are those that would be used by the husband, who is called □ε9, when speaking directly to them. When speaking about them he precedes the terms by ko·3, meaning “my”. He adds the word na4, “great”, before each term when speaking about the relatives of another person. On the right are the names of the husband for his own ancestors, on the left his names for his wife's ancestors. The wife uses the same terms for the husband's ancestors that the husband does. If the husband wishes he may call the ancestors of his wife by the same names as he would his own. Both the husband and the wife call the descendants by the same terms or names. The wife calls her own ancestors by the same names or terms that the husband does his ancestors.' [907]
♠ bravery ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Schein mentions bravery as being attributed to the Hmong, but it is unclear to which degree bravery was culturally valued at the time: 'Rebellious by Character Many sketches have been made of what might be described a Miao “national character,” pointing to collections of personal traits and emotional dispositions attributed to the group as a whole. In their many characterizations by Westerners, the Miao have been painted as “passionate, easily offended, suspicious, revengeful, brave, and indifferent to hunger and cold” (Edkins 1870:74), as “friendly and hospitable” (Betts 1900-1901:104), as “a very lovable people, quick to recognize right and wrong, kind and gentle in their association with one another, buoyant and joyous, and at times industrious almost beyond belief” (Crisler 1937:51-52), as “much given to litigation” (Clarke 1907:258), and as “warlike, frank, lawless, primitive, openhearted, opposed to trading and city life” (Kemp 1921:177). Miao self-description and recent mainstream Chinese portrayals have emphasized other attributes, equally as reified. In one rendition, they are considered to have common psychological qualities (gongtong xinli suzhi) such as being “warmhearted and forthright” (requing haoshuang), “loving and pursuing freedom” (re'ai he zhuiqiu ziyou), having a strong “pioneer spirit and the ability to live on their own” (kaituo jingshen yu ziwo shengcun negli) (Yang 1989:19). Fei Hsiao-t'ung praised their willingness to labor, calling them “qinlao de Miaozu” (the hardworking Miao) (1988:31) as well as “ke ai de” (likable, lovely) (1988:36).' [908] More information is needed.
♠ respect for property ♣ present ♥ Most Hmong were smallholders or tenants: 'Prior to the 1950s land reform, some Miao were smallholders. Many, if not most, were tenants on lands owned by Han, Yi, Hui, and others. Few were true landlords, and most who rented out land were likely to work part of their holdings themselves with family labor. All land is now owned by the state, including undeveloped mountain and forest lands, thus limiting any expansion beyond lands officially assigned to an individual or village. In the process, pastoralism and forest hunting/gathering have been reduced. Before land reform, some Miao areas followed the practice of lineage or hamlet ownership of mountain and hillside lands even where some private holdings existed. People could open new lands for farming and settlement, share village pastures, or hunt away from their home area.' [909] 'Miao everywhere, and by all reports, were agriculturalists, often tenants, and rarely landlords, except in Southeast Guizhou where they were more prosperous and more class-differentiated. They typically lived in small villages averaging ten to twenty households on mountain slopes remote from centers of Han settlement. In some places, village orientations were determined by geomancy, or “feng shui.” Their houses were constructed of wood, stone, or mud brick, depending on location. Using either swidden or paddy methods, they grew a variety of grains, including wet and dry rice, maize, buckwheat, millet, barley, gaoliang, and wheat. Their diet was supplemented with the cultivation of potatoes, vegetables, beans, and rape (for oil), with eggs and tofu, with hunting, and with domestic chicken, fish, pork, and occasionally beef. Opium, tobacco, and liquor also were produced, and different regions boasted other trade products such as tung oil, lacquer, herbal medicines, wool, and, most importantly, timber. They manufactured their own clothes with homegrown cotton, hemp, indigo, and other natural dyes and with techniques of weaving, dyeing, embroidery, and batik.' [910] The monogamous family was the basic socio-economic unit: 'The basic social organization /sic/ of the Miao is the family, and moreover their family structure is the small family system, which consists of husband, wife, and children under age. This kind of small family system is the original system of the Miao. The Miao Fang Pei Lan, in the chapter on villages, says: “Among the Miao people father and sons and brothers do not live together in one house. When a son grows up he lives apart, erecting a new house and then there is another household.” Because of the small family system their living quarters as a rule consist of two or three rooms. In the house there is only one bed, and the husband, wife, and children all sleep on it together. When a girl grows up, a separate bed may be set up for her. As a rule the Miao practice monogamy. Sometimes they take a concubine, to live together with the wife, or to live separately. In the family economy, men and women share agricultural work, but household chores are mainly the women's responsibility. Family property consists of fields, houses, animals, and furniture, tools, and utensils. When the children grow up, a boy gets married at 17 or 18, and is given a certain amount of property in order to build a separate house and establish a family. A girl marries at fifteen or sixteen. So, the small family system among the Miao can always be maintained, and is not likely to be expanded.' [911] Youngest sons were preferred heirs, but other children received property at marriage: 'At marriage, sons and daughters receive property and assistance in building a new house. Marriage portions previously included livestock as well as household goods, tools, jewelry, and cloth. The youngest son and his descendants inherit the parental house and remaining wealth. A couple without sons will live with a daughter, who stands as heir.' [912] 'Boys were more desired than girls because inheritance is in the male line and sons carry on the worship of ancestors, as among the Chinese, but girls were also loved and desired. They had a greater economic value than among the Chinese because of the work they did even after they were married. They also kept closer contact with their parents after marriage than Chinese girls can do. This was indicated by the fact that they took their maiden name, even though they remained in the home of the deceased husband.' [913] Material wealth was transmitted patrilineally and ornaments/family heirlooms were transmitted matrilineally: 'Miao society was predominantly patrilineal and generally organized [Page 53] in terms of exogamous village/lineage units. A patronymic system was widespread with surnames, of which there were no more than ten or twenty in use, borrowed from the Chinese. These surname groups constituted clanlike structures, which for purposes of mutual aid and large-scale rituals occasionally superseded the otherwise local village and patrilineal political organization. In some areas neolocal and/or matrilocal residence was found, but patrilocal residence was the most common. Premarital sex and courtship were characteristic among the Miao in most places, and arranged marriage was primarily according to the right of priority of a girl's maternal uncle to marry her to his son. Courtship took place at markets and festivals in which a special site sometimes was found for mingling, dancing, or antiphonal singing. Bride-price and sometimes dowry were provided by parents, once they approved their children's choices of partners. In some places, delayed transfer marriage was practiced, and divorce was acceptable, especially before the first child. Polygyny was uncommon, but not unknown. Inheritance was patrilineal, except for heirloom clothing and silver jewelry, which passed through the matriline.' [914] 'Inheritance. The family was the social unit. Descent was through males and the oldest living male was the head of the family. Non-personal property belonged to the family as a whole and even clothing and ornaments might be passed around, especially when one or more represented the family on some social occasion. Then, in order to do honor to the family and to their hosts, they made a display of the family wealth. A woman owned the [Page [42b]] ornaments she bought or had given her and the embroidery she made. She gave most of her ornaments to her daughters.' [915] Mutual aid among siblings was practiced even after the passing of their parents: 'The possessions of the family as a whole were in land and animals. After the death of both parents the sons usually divided up the property, but all continued to work together in the cultivation of rice and the chief winter crops, leaving the care of gardens to the women of each household. If there were several married sons in a family, some had homes of their own, but they still gave mutual help. Some families had fairly extensive holdings in various directions from the village, but almost entirely in this one valley.' [916] The fact that material possessions were inherited within the family suggests that some 'respect for property' was present.

♠ Moralistic punishment by human religious agents ♣ absent ♥ absent/present/unknown. Shamans and diviners performed ritual services for their communities. eHRAF provides the following general summary: 'Religious beliefs and activities vary by locale and subethnic identity. The situation is further complicated by partial adoption of elements of folk Daoism and Buddhism, or by conversion to Christianity (as among segments of the White and Flowery Miao). Traditional religious beliefs concern powerful suprahuman forces associated with sacred groves, stones, caves, and other natural phenomena, as well as with bridges and wells. Other protective spirits guard the household and hamlet. The latter are sometimes thought of as dragons. It is believed that at death, the soul divides into three parts, one of which returns to protect the household as an ancestral spirit. There is also concern with evil spirits and with ghosts of those who died bad deaths and who may cause illness and misfortune. Religious beliefs are supported by a complex series of sung or chanted poetic myths, which treat the creation of the universe, the doings of divine beings and culture heroes, and early Miao history.' [917] 'Most religious ritual is performed or guided by various part-time specialists who act as priests, diviners, or shamans for the local community or for kin groups. Most of them are males. They engage in ordinary work, and only the most important religious activities require them to don special items of dress and decoration to mark them from others. There are no written texts for learning the chants, songs, dances, and rituals: they are memorized. If called by a family, specialists receive a small payment (often in foodstuffs) for their assistance. Shamans play a key role at funerals and postburial rites. They are also involved in analysis and healing of illness: some are skilled in herbal medicine as well as ritual procedures. Shamans also provide explanations of the possible causes of misfortune and can provide protective amulets. Ceremonies on behalf of the village community or a gathering of kin from several villages are conducted by skilled male elders who function as priests, following ritual procedures, administering the necessary animal and food sacrifices, and chanting the songs and myths without going into trance or communicating directly with the supernaturals and spirits. Some ceremonies are led by the male head of household on behalf of his immediate family.' [918] 'The calendrical year holds a number of set ceremonies that vary from group to group in content, purpose, and timing. For example, as of the 1990s some groups celebrated the lunar New Year along with their Han neighbors, whereas others celebrated the year's start in the tenth lunar month, following the harvest, and marked it with bullfights and cattle sacrifices. Others marked the New Year with cockfights or sacrifice of pigs and chickens, or intervillage assemblages enlivened by antiphonal singing, dancing, and the playing of the lusheng . Among the important festivals found in many (not all) Miao communities are the Dragon Boat Festival, which is synchronic with the Han festivities to a large extent, and the Mountain Flower festivals, which were an important institution for bringing together marriageable young people from different hamlets. The Drum Society festivals are held by dispersed kin groups to honor their ancestors every seven, ten, or twelve years, and are not strictly tied to the calendar. Most festivals involve the lavish offering of animal sacrifices, and for this reason the state has discouraged them.' [919] Schein paints a similar picture: 'Miao religious practices comprised animistic, ancestor worship, and shamanistic elements. Animal sacrifice and other forms of propitiation were key parts of all these practices. For ceremonies and exorcisms, and sometimes depending on the nature of the occasion, ritual experts and shamans could be male or female, and they were skilled in incantations, animal sacrifice, and the manipulation of various objects. They were engaged for a variety of healing purposes as well as for life-cycle rituals. Other sorcerers, particularly women, operated surreptitiously in the practice of so-called gu witchcraft in which they controlled others through harm or the threat of harm inflicted by poisons gleaned from [Page 54] insects. In addition to these belief systems, a considerable (but never tallied) number of Miao had converted to Christianity beginning in the nineteenth century.' [920] Shamans and healers performed divinations and sacrifices: 'The tuan kung □ called in Ch'uan Miao To.3 n□n6 is the person who exorcises demons, and thus heals diseases and wards off other calamities that are caused by demons.
